content.description: Face climb between Alexandra David Neal and the arete on the right.  The route is fairly straight.  If you set your top rope right you can do both this and Alexandra David Neal on the same rope.  Even slide over a bit to do Old Stump if you didn't want to Lead it.
content.protection: Anchors further back with cams/hexes/nuts.  Easy to top belay.
content.location: A few feet right of Alexandra David Neal and just left of the arete.

content.description:
Starts out easy the crux is pulling the final moves.  The crux is well protected with a small stopper.  For an easier exit work right at the top (5.6). 

 RCM&W #67, p.47.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Standard top rope set up.
content.location: This route begins in a small dihedral about 5 feet to the right of Ivy Right in a corner.

content.description:
A fun route.  The bottom of the climb is fairly easy 5.6ish.  The real fun begins at the top where you'll be glad you brought that big piece. 

 RCM&W #67, p.46.
content.protection: Nuts, Hexes, Cams including a larger piece such as #11 BD hexentric, #4 Camalot or equivalent Big Bro.  Standard top rope setup.
content.location: This route lies in the obvious corner first visible from the approach trail.  It lies to the left of Ivy Right and the right of Gulliver's travels.

content.description:
An excellent beginner climb or first lead.  This route follows the crack system straight to the top. 

 RCM&W #68, p.47.
content.protection: Nuts and hexes.  Bring cams if you trust them in quartzite.  Standard top rope setup.
content.location: This route lies to the right of Jasper's Dihedral and to the left of Old Stump.

content.description: The face between Ivy Right and Old Stump.
content.location: The face between Ivy Right and Old Stump.  Access via the class 3 gully on back of the buttress.

content.description:
Follow the small holds trying to make a direct line with a small corner on the top of the wall.  The hardest part for me was finding the holds. 

 RCM&W #66, p.46.
content.location: The start of this route is about 6 feet to the left of Jasper's Dihedral

content.description:
Follow a relatively straight line on small edges.  The hardest part for me was locating the holds. 

 RCM&W #64, p.46.
content.location: The first top rope problem on the buttress.  This route starts about 5 feet right of the corner of the buttress, and about 5 feet to the left of Black Wall, starting to the left of a thin seam.

content.description:
Climb to a small roof (crux) on small edges and make your way to the top. 

 RCM&W #65, p.46.
content.location: The middle line between Black and Blue Bulge and Gulliver's Travels.

content.description: This is an excellent climb that is completely independent of Jasper's Dihedral, but can be done off the same rope.  The climbing is great and offers some of the best exposure at Blue Mounds - an excellent line.  Enjoy!!
content.location: This is the arete just to the right of Jasper's Dihedral.  You sort of bounce around on either side of the arete following the holds.

content.description: Face climbing with a fairly definitive crux half way up.
content.location: 6 feet to the right of Old Stump.

content.description: This is one of the most popular areas in Blue Mounds.  Saturday Buttress is located between Many Cracks Buttress and Midnight Buttress.  It contains a number of really fun leads Ivy Right (5.5), Old Stump (5.7), and Jasper's Dihedral (5.8) as well as several moderate top rope problems:  Gulliver's Travels (5.7+), Black and Blue Bulge (5.8+), and Black Wall (5.9).  The cliff is clearly visible from the paved trail.
